bent upwards). 

This model has been around since the 19th century and has regained
its popularity in recent years. 

The term Granny Bike stems from the old
fashioned image of the bicycle. 

There are many different types of Dutch
Bicycles available (with a classic coaster brake, with a hand brake, with or

title: Peugeot folding bicycle
text: During the 1970s the French manufacturer, Cycles Peugeot, produced a folding bicycle (internal code F13) which was sold through Peugeot car dealerships. For sale is such a vintage folding bicycle purchased in 1975. As shown in one of the photos, its serial number is 2714006.The U-shaped frame splits in two when folding. It is normally held together by means of a substantial bolt at the bottom of the U. The bike has a quick-release handlebar post to make it easier to turn the handlebars lengthwise to facilitate loading. It has front caliper brakes and a back-pedal rear hub.Wheel size is 20 x 1.75 and white sidewall tyres in that size are still available ! (as I discovered when I had to replace the front tyre).There has been a resurgence of interest in vintage folding bikes recently. There is currently one on eBay at about R8 800, shipping excluded. (See https://www.ebay.com/itm/275591345378)The best thing about this classic folding bike is that it is supremely practical. It is easy to ride on city streets, it handles well, it is utterly reliable and feels sturdy and comfortable. It is, after all, a Peugeot from the days when they built the venerated 504 sedan, considered by many to be one of the best cars ever seen on our roads. Its practicality is moreover combined with the versatility of a folding bike which can be easily carried in the back of an SUV or bakkie.The bike is in excellent shape, considering its age. There are some blemishes on the paintwork from an anti-rust product, and some very light surface rust on the rims and chrome surfaces. It has no serious or structural rust, having always been stored in a dry garage.

Key Bike Features:Genuine brown leather hand-stitched gripsTouring saddleAlloy kickstandFounded in Venice, California in 2007, Linus Bicycles see bicycles as a practical solution to some big problems. They improve our health and wellbeing, reduce carbon emissions, and make our communities and neighborhoods more livable and more connected. Designed for purpose. Linus bikes are built to replace small car trips, that means they are ridden everyday and often carry additional weight like groceries or kids. As a result Linus bikes prioritize comfort and durability, selecting materials and parts that can stand up to constant use. If you use a car analogy, everyone appreciates the high performance sports car- but it’s not the car you drive every day… it’s not comfortable and needs constant maintenance. title: Scott Cr1 20 Full Carbon Road Bike for Sale at. Bargain!!
text:
The Scott CR1 is a historic carbon-fiber frame adapted for contemporary needs. It"™s a no-frills endurance bike that"™s light and handles well. 

When the CR1 was introduced, it started the carbon-fiber wars. It was lighter than anything else on the market, and it was tough enough to be raced at the top of the ProTour. It came and conquered the pro ranks, in particular mountain stages in Grand Tours. Back then, it was set-up with top-of "“the-line componentry and tubulars to give pro"™s what was a nearly unheard-of thing, a fifteen-pound road bike. 

The IMP or Integrated Molding Process was the key. They were able to create highly-compacted oversized tube shapes and provide a stiff, light ride. 

Scott kept developing and developing. The Addict became their top dog. But they reimagined the CR1 as an endurance bike. They kept it light, tweaked the geometry, and improved the comfort. They developed flex zones for vertical compliance in the stays. And they scaled down the fork blades for greater comfort as well. It"™s now more of an endurance/Gran Fondo geometry, with a taller head tube and stays slimmed and shaped for comfort. But it"™s still a sub-1,000g frame (940g). One that has been raced in the cobblestone classics. 

Endurance geometry from Scott is still pretty fast, but with more stack (or front end height), and less reach (or top tube length). You won"™t need a roll of spacers under your stem to keep the stem low and stiff. And you won"™t have to resort to a short stem even if you can"™t reach far. All day comfort is favored over twitchiness. 

There are some holdovers from the older days. The straight 1 1/8" steerer and 31.6mm seatpost were on the original bike and are still here. The oversized seat tube is stiff, but the S-bend stays (the flex zone mentioned above), damp road vibrations before they reach the post. Cable-routing is external and designed for mechanical shifting and braking only. External cabling is something that mechanics prefer, as it"™s easier to install, easier to work on. 

The Scott CR1 is a classic bike, both in terms of how long it has been around, and how well it rides in classic races.
